Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EaSM3 Integration of Decision-Making with Predictive Capacity for Decadal Climate Impacts
Award.AbstractNarration:
The need for climate impact predictions on regional and decadal scales is widely recognized. Industry, government and society increasingly require predictive information in decision-relevant terms to enable appropriate planning and adaptation to future hazards arising from climate variability and change, both to mitigate future costs and maximize potential benefits. Climate scientists are engaged in significant effort to understand the decadal predictability of the climate system and to develop models to predict the climate on 5-30 year timescales. However, parallel efforts to understand predictive capacity of climate impacts and realize the full societal value of decadal prediction science has received little attention.

This collaborative project will utilize existing and developing dynamical models combined with observed data using advanced statistical methods to understand our predictive capacity for climate impacts on decadal timescales, and integrate predictive methods so that they more directly meet the societal needs for predictive information. The overarching goal is to transform how scientists from multiple disciplines and practitioners conceptualize decadal climate prediction, by enabling decadal predictions in decision relevant terms to improve planning and adaptive capacity for climate variability and change.

The approach follows in two concurrent parts. Understanding of current predictive information needs and usage will be developed in Part I across multiple high-impact weather and climate phenomena and across multiple stakeholder groups. The core research will take place in Part II and will identify our predictive capacity for the needed information through development of new combined statistical-dynamical modeling approaches that incorporate and are robust to uncertainty. An iterative process between information needs and information provision will promote effective integration of skillful predictive information with decision-making. A key project contribution is the development of a prototype generalized interdisciplinary research framework to integrate predictive capacity with decision-making.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Decadal climate predictions provide climate information one to ten years in the future, and bridge the gap between shorter-term seasonal forecasts and longer-term climate projections. Although seasonal and climate outlooks are now used across various sectors of climate risk management, the societal value of these decadal climate predictions is relatively unexplored. This multi-year project - called UDECIDE (Understanding Decision Climate Interactions on Decadal Scales) - identified new opportunities for creating usable climate information on decadal timescales.

A novel research framework integrating atmospheric science, engineering, statistics, and social sciences was implemented to work towards realizing usable decadal climate information. We focused on case studies of flood risk and water resource management in Colorado and California. The framework (Figure 1) consisted of a stakeholder-oriented research stream and a climate research stream that became increasingly combined as the project progressed. Foundation elements of each research stream mapped the landscapes of the current state of decadal climate prediction and predictability and decadal-climate related stakeholder decisions. Later, integration elements combined the research streams, towards the creation of usable climate information. Our research team included the training of three graduate students and three early career scientists within the project’s highly interdisciplinary research environment.

For water resource management, we found broad scope for integrating decadal climate predictions into decisions, particularly in California, which experiences the strongest and most well understood decadal variability compared to Colorado. From this starting point, we developed a new statistical climate model that identified new, stronger connections between California precipitation and the potentially predictable ocean temperature patterns. Using climate model simulations, we also found large changes in the frequency of the strongest storms on 1-10-year time scales. 

We used these new climate science results to inform the design of presentations of decadal prediction data, and discussed these with water agency stakeholders in California to explore how decadal predictions could be provided in usable ways. Predictions presented alongside projections and historical climate ranges are potential usable in scenario planning, and to narrow near-term climate uncertainty. This would help water agencies to prioritize near-term investments, avoid stranded assets, and facilitate difficult conversations with stakeholders about how to manage competing demands on resources. Further, information on near-term climate excursions beyond normal operating conditions may be usable in planning for the associated risks, but also in taking the opportunity to test new management strategies. Combined temperature and precipitation presentations are potentially usable in creating situational awareness for changed likelihood of climate conditions that raise flood and water supply risks. Perhaps most importantly, stakeholders stressed that the full range of information down to the weather scale is more useful. This is perhaps where our project was most successful at converging the stakeholder and climate research (a key intellectual merit of the project): We advanced the physical science by understanding decadal variability at the scales most desired by the stakeholders.

Stakeholders stated that while atmospheric climate metrics are useful for raising situational awareness, the most useful variables are hydrologic in nature such as reservoir inflows. This is where we identified a new, specific role for boundary organizations within our research framework. The ongoing projects of Jacobs - our engineering firm collaborative partner - with some of the water managers allowed us to explore the advantages of communicating decadal climate information in formats familiar to the managers. We also explored a case study application of skillful multi-year temperature predictions to a specific hydrologic impact model, and showed that temperature offers a marginal source of streamflow predictability. The potential to put research results into practice within these ongoing and planned future projects is a key broader impact of the project and strengthens stakeholder investment in the research.

Many of the identified potential uses require information beyond current understanding and predictive capacity of climate on multi-year timescales, particularly for extreme quantities. This represents a broader impact of the research and an opportunity to align the future trajectory of the climate science with stakeholders' information needs.

In summary this project illustrates the effectiveness of this type of multi-method, integrated research framework in working towards creating usable predictive climate information at decadal timescales. Further, the framework is general and could be applied to other climate regions and decision contexts, representing a significant broader impact of the project. The rapid evolution of decadal climate science and availability of real-time predictions, combined with clear societal need, presents new opportunities to create usable climate information. Recent events such as the Oroville Dam failure in California in 2017 and the devastating wildfire season of 2020 in California and Colorado indicate that creating usable multi-year climate outlooks is more important than ever.
